text: There hasn't been a tonne of messaging - really just follow UK government guidelines, wash your hands properly and frequently, and cancel all non-essential work travel. Still working in the office here in London as normal.

Hello <@UUH28N3U2>, this article follows HubSpot's definition and provides a pretty good explanation. I recently started a new position and found that the sales team decides the factors to determine the difference between a SQL and MQL. Hope that helps:
<https://www.smartbugmedia.com/blog/handing-leads-off-to-sales-the-mql-vs-sql-difference|https://www.smartbugmedia.com/blog/handing-leads-off-to-sales-the-mql-vs-sql-difference>

attachments.title: Handing Leads Off to Sales & the MQL vs SQL Difference
attachments.text: Determining a MQL from a SQL takes a partnership, and determining a MQL vs a SQL helps marketing know when to hand off leads to sales.

text:
Hi, everyone! I'm new here and excited to get to know everyone.

I have a general question about content marketers' backgrounds. I feel like I've seen a lot of shifts lately in terms of what employers look for (different skills like product marketing vs. communications) and where content sits on the org chart (under product marketing or under demand gen vs. directly under the head of marketing). I'd love to hear everyone's thoughts and experiences.

*In general, what are your skills? Who do you report into? Any shifts or trends you've seen recently in hiring?*

To kick off the conversation, I can start: I hopped all over the content world, working as a lifestyle writer, an advertising copywriter, and a freelance journalist, before settling into content marketing, where I've spent the last 5-6 years. At my last job, I specialized in PR and running content-based campaigns (like writing an ebook and all the ad, email, and promotional copy that goes along with it). At my current job, campaigns falls under demand gen, so I'm focusing more on communications here. I currently report into the head of marketing, but I've recently talked to a few heads of marketing who structure things differently.

Curious what you all have seen and if you have predictions for where content marketing is heading!

elements.text:
Hi, everyone! I'm new here and excited to get to know everyone.

I have a general question about content marketers' backgrounds. I feel like I've seen a lot of shifts lately in terms of what employers look for (different skills like product marketing vs. communications) and where content sits on the org chart (under product marketing or under demand gen vs. directly under the head of marketing). I'd love to hear everyone's thoughts and experiences.
In general, what are your skills? Who do you report into? Any shifts or trends you've seen recently in hiring?

To kick off the conversation, I can start: I hopped all over the content world, working as a lifestyle writer, an advertising copywriter, and a freelance journalist, before settling into content marketing, where I've spent the last 5-6 years. At my last job, I specialized in PR and running content-based campaigns (like writing an ebook and all the ad, email, and promotional copy that goes along with it). At my current job, campaigns falls under demand gen, so I'm focusing more on communications here. I currently report into the head of marketing, but I've recently talked to a few heads of marketing who structure things differently.

Curious what you all have seen and if you have predictions for where content marketing is heading!

text:
Good question! I’d be interested to hear what others have to say.

I come from an agency background and I started off in social media marketing/advertising/data analytics with some SEO sprinkled in. I then moved to a different company, which prioritized organic content a lot more (blog, video, ebook etc.) – I think, in part, because the marketing manager was very big on branding/content/storytelling. I also saw content-based campaigns were performing a lot better.

Now, I’m going freelance and what I’ve seen is that the ROI on ads is going down across the board and so more people are investing in content.

elements.text:
Good question! I’d be interested to hear what others have to say.

I come from an agency background and I started off in social media marketing/advertising/data analytics with some SEO sprinkled in. I then moved to a different company, which prioritized organic content a lot more (blog, video, ebook etc.) – I think, in part, because the marketing manager was very big on branding/content/storytelling. I also saw content-based campaigns were performing a lot better.

Now, I’m going freelance and what I’ve seen is that the ROI on ads is going down across the board and so more people are investing in content.

text: I am really curious here too. I currently report to the vp of marketing but my role will eventually evolve into demand gen (but I’ll still be reporting to marketing). I have a background in journalism, business marketing and creative. I’d say one of the most important aspects is to have experience in creative but an interest in data - the data is really important! Also market research tactics have been important for building buyer personas - and also a good relationship with the sales team to be able to define the sales funnel.

text:
Great topic!

*My background*
I'm a mechanical engineer originally, who fell out of interest with that industry and got curious about tech startups. I've always enjoyed reading and writing, so thought a content marketing job in a tech startup would be a good fit!

*My skills*
The way I used to frame this when trying to crack into the industry was that my engineering background gave me an analytical mindset and my interest in reading and writing gave me a creative flair. Since being away from academia and the engineering industry for so long, I've definitely tilted more towards an almost _pie in the sky_ creative dreamer. :sweat_smile:

*Who I report to*
CMO > Global Head of Comms > Head of Content > Me. It's worth noting that where I am, at GoCardless, demand gen isn't a formal team, it's considered more of a function/output of the marketing team. And product marketing is a separate team, not at all reporting into that Global Head of Comms.

*Trends I've seen in hiring*
Other than me, I think all the content people at GoCardless have had formal marketing education or extensive marketing/writing/editing/journalism backgrounds. This is only my second content role, having previously built the content marketing function at a much smaller tech startup (as a team of one! :sweat_smile:)

text:
Hi Brittany,

I took an unconventional path into content marketing. I started my career in retail sales, then IT, and transitioned into a general marketing manager role for a financial services firm. I’m self-taught but have an academic background in design and media arts. So I would say the primary skills that have carried me so far are writing, creative problem-solving, and (although it sounds trite) empathy for the customer. Secondary skills are a basic understanding of technology and tools, organic SEO, basic analytics, and an eye for design/layout/video.

I currently report directly to a SVP of marketing on a small-ish, flat team. But I also consult weekly with our Chief Strategy Officer, to ensure his vision is carried through all our messaging and copy. Part of my role is working closely with our designer and our demand gen team to produce and promote our content. And part of my role is working closely with Sales Enablement and equipping the sales team with the right messages through tools like first-call prompters and email starter templates.

Over the past eight or nine years, my content marketing roles have sat in various places in the org, and have been defined very differently—“Content Marketing Manager” apparently means anything from copywriter to content marketing strategist, to marketing director, depending on the size of the company and the leadership. But I think it works best when you report directly to the head of marketing or head of growth. Content itself can span across marketing and sales and even customer success, and I think it’s most successful when the message is consistent across every customer-facing team. That said, very few orgs seem to understand that (in my experience).
